{{flagicon image|Flag of the Moro Islamic Liberation Front.svg}} [[Moro Islamic Liberation Front]] | ratifiers = | depositor = | language = | wikisource = }} The '''Comprehensive Agreement on Bangsamoro''' ('''CAB''') is a final peace agreement signed between the [[Government of the Philippines]] and the [[Moro Islamic Liberation Front]] on 27 March 2014 at the [[Malacañang Palace|Malacañang Palace]] in [[Manila]].{{cite web|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/588852/500-milf-members-to-attend-bangsamoro-accord-signing-at-palace |title=500 MILF members to attend Bangsamoro accord signing at Palace | Inquirer News |publisher=Newsinfo.inquirer.net |date=2014-03-25 |accessdate=2015-02-27}} Under the agreement, the Islamic separatists would turn over their firearms to a third party, which would be selected by the rebels and the Philippine government. The MILF agreed to decommission its armed wing, the Bangsamoro Islamic Armed Forces (BIAF). In return, the government would establish an autonomous [[Bangsamoro (political entity)|Bangsamoro]]. Power sharing was a central point to the autonomy redesign. The current ARMM charter lists 14 areas that are outside the powers of the regional legislature. In this comprehensive peace agreement, the parties lists 81 powers categorized into reserved for the central government, exclusive to the Bangsamoro, and concurrent with or shared by the two sides for power sharing. Of the 81 powers, 58 are devolved to the Bangsamoro, nine are reserved to the central government, and 14 are shared.{{cite web|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/589347/power-sharing-central-to-moro-self-rule |title=Power-sharing central to Moro self-rule | Inquirer News |publisher=Newsinfo.inquirer.net |date=2014-03-27 |accessdate=2015-02-27}} The [[Framework Agreement on the Bangsamoro]] and Four annexes, namely on Transitional Arrangements and Modalities, Revenue Generation and Wealth Sharing, Power Sharing and Normalization, together with the Addendum on Bangsamoro Waters, will be included in the comprehensive agreement.{{cite web|last=Rodel |first=Jose |url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2014/02/12/1289375/bangsamoro-deal-signed-march |title=Bangsamoro deal signed by March | Headlines, News, The Philippine Star |publisher=philstar.com |date=2014-02-12 |accessdate=2015-02-27}} The Armed Forces of the Philippines has raised red alert status on 24 March in preparation for the event. Philippine President [[Benigno Aquino III]], [[Moro Islamic Liberation Front|MILF]] chair [[Hadji Murad Ibrahim]], and Malaysian Prime Minister [[Najib Razak]] are among the key people expected to be present at the signing of the agreement.{{cite web|last=Romero |first=Alexis |url=http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2014/03/25/1304996/afp-red-alert-vs.-peace-deal-spoilers |title=AFP on red alert vs. peace deal spoilers | Headlines, News, The Philippine Star |publisher=philstar.com |date=2014-03-25 |accessdate=2015-02-27}} ==Background== {{see also|Moro insurgency in the Philippines}} In pursuit of their goal of liberating [[Bangsamoro Republik|Bangsamoro]], the MNLF engaged the [[Armed Forces of the Philippines|government forces]] in extensive armed collisions,{{cite web|url=http://publishing.cdlib.org/ucpressebooks/view?docId=ft0199n64c;chunk.id=0;doc.view=print |title=Muslim Rulers and Rebels |publisher=Publishing.cdlib.org |date= |accessdate=2015-02-27}} peaking in the early 70s when the rebels’ blitz-like operations brought them control of a substantial number of municipalities surrounding [[Cotabato City]] and its airport complex. This prompted the [[Ferdinand Marcos|Marcos]] regime to beef up military presence by deploying almost three-fourths of the army{{cite web|url=http://asiasociety.org/countries/conflicts/origins-muslim-separatist-movement-philippines?page=0,1 |title=The Origins of the Muslim Separatist Movement in the Philippines |publisher=Asia Society |date= |accessdate=2015-02-27}} in most Muslim parts of [[Mindanao]]. Things took a different turn in 1976 when [[Libya]]n leader [[Muammar Gaddafi]] brokered an agreement{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QqgiE94IAmIC |title=Militant Islam in Southeast Asia: Crucible of Terror - Zachary Abuza - Google Books |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2015-02-27}} that led to the signing of the Tripoli Agreement{{cite web|url=http://mnlfnet.com/The_Tripoli.htm |title=MNLF Home Page |publisher=Mnlfnet.com |date= |accessdate=2015-02-27}}, introducing the concept of an autonomous Muslim region in Mindanao. On 1 August 1989, under the mandate of the new 1987 Constitution,{{cite web|url=http://elibrary.judiciary.gov.ph/index7.php?doctype=Constitutions&docid=a45475a11ec72b843d74959b60fd7bd64558f82c40d9d#sam |accessdate=27 March 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121028105057/http://elibrary.judiciary.gov.ph/index7.php?doctype=Constitutions&docid=a45475a11ec72b843d74959b60fd7bd64558f82c40d9d |archivedate=28 October 2012 }} [[Congress of the Philippines|Congress]] enacted Republic Act 6734{{cite web|url=http://www.lawphil.net/statutes/repacts/ra1989/ra_6734_1989.html |title=R.A. 6734 |publisher=Lawphil.net |date=1989-08-01 |accessdate=2015-02-27}}, authorizing the creation of the [[Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao]] (ARMM). However, out of the 13 provinces and 9 cities that participated in the plebiscite,{{cite web|url=http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/research/08/10/08/fast-facts-armm-elections|title=Fast Facts on the ARMM Elections|publisher=Abs-cbnnews.com|accessdate=2015-02-27}} only the provinces of [[Lanao del Sur]], [[Maguindanao]], [[Sulu]], and [[Tawi-Tawi]] opted to become part of the ARMM. The ARMM was formally established on 6 November 1990.{{cite web|url=http://unterm.un.org/DGAACS/unterm.nsf/8fa942046ff7601c85256983007ca4d8/7098d74184207a3385256b040066f055?OpenDocument |title=Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao |publisher=[[United Nations Multilingual Terminology Database|Unterm.un.org]] |date= |accessdate=2015-02-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131015020445/http://unterm.un.org/DGAACS/unterm.nsf/8fa942046ff7601c85256983007ca4d8/7098d74184207a3385256b040066f055?OpenDocument |archivedate=15 October 2013 |df=dmy }} Instead of bringing the Muslim leaders together, this agreement further fragmented the MNLF,{{cite web|url=http://www.fas.org/irp/world/para/mnlf.htm |title=Moro National Liberation Front (MNLF) |publisher=Fas.org |date= |accessdate=2015-02-27}} because some factions within the group preferred independence over autonomy. Thus, a group of officers led by [[Hashim Salamat]] broke away{{cite web|url=http://www.cdi.org/terrorism/moro.cfm |accessdate=27 March 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120909040310/http://www.cdi.org/terrorism/moro.cfm |archivedate=9 September 2012 }} and formed the [[Moro Islamic Liberation Front]] (MILF) to continue their armed struggle for an independent Bangsamoro (Moro nation) in Mindanao. Though the combined strength of these two rebel forces has not reached a point of posing any real threat to the [[Government of the Philippines|government]] in [[Manila]], their existence—and the reasons for their resilience—certainly brings lots of headaches for the government. For nearly five decades, five [[President of the Philippines|presidents]] have tried to completely end these two rebellions, utilizing both [[Military force|force]] and [[diplomacy]]. So far, no combination has succeeded. Perhaps the most remarkable effort to bring closure to these movements was that of the [[Fidel V. Ramos|Ramos]] Administration, which tried to reach out to both the communist and Muslim rebels through peaceful means. There were many [[Peace process with the Bangsamoro in the Philippines#Efforts to reach peace with Islamic separatists|efforts to reach peace with Islamist separatists]]. ==Framework Agreement== {{Main|Framework Agreement on the Bangsamoro}} On 15 October 2012, the Philippine government signed a much-hyped document touted as the [[Framework Agreement on the Bangsamoro]], which culminated the Aquino Administration's effort to end the deadlock in the peace process. This new document, while merely providing for a general framework for the actual peace negotiations, announced that "the status quo is unacceptable and that the Bangsamoro shall be established to replace the Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao (ARMM). The Bangsamoro was the new autonomous political entity (NPE) referred to in the Decision Points of Principles as of April 2012." According to President [[Benigno Aquino III|Aquino]], this was the agreement that could "finally seal genuine, lasting peace in Mindanao."{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.gov.ph/2012/10/15/speech-of-president-aquino-during-the-signing-of-the-gph-milf-framework-agreement-october-15-2012/%20 |title=Speech of President Aquino during the signing of the GPH-MILF Framework Agreement on the Bangsamoro, October 15, 2012 | Official Gazette of the Republic of the Philippines |publisher=Gov.ph |date=2012-10-15 |accessdate=2015-02-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131228173309/http://www.gov.ph/2012/10/15/speech-of-president-aquino-during-the-signing-of-the-gph-milf-framework-agreement-october-15-2012/ |archivedate=28 December 2013 |df=dmy }} with [[Bangsamoro (political entity)|Bangsamoro]] replacing ARMM which was described by [[President of the Philippines|President]] [[Benigno Aquino III]] as "a failed experiment".{{cite web|url=http://www.gmanetwork.com/news/story/277218/news/nation/govt-milf-agree-to-create-bangsamoro-to-replace-armm |title=Govt, MILF agree to create ‘Bangsamoro’ to replace ARMM | News | GMA News Online |publisher=Gmanetwork.com |date=2012-10-07 |accessdate=2015-02-27}} ==Reaching the agreement== The peace talks between the MILF and the [[Philippine government]] had been brokered by [[Malaysia]] since 1997. After 2009, the negotiations were also supported by an International Contact Group(the ICG).{{cite web|url=http://www.c-r.org/sites/c-r.org/files/PracticePaper_MindanaoICG_ConciliationResources_0.pdf|format=PDF|title=Innovation in mediation support: The International Contact Group in Mindanao|publisher=C-r.org|accessdate=2015-02-27}} The ICG represented an innovation in peace process support, in that it was a hybrid body composed of both states and international non-governmental organisations (INGOs). The members were [[Turkey]], [[Saudi Arabia]], the [[United Kingdom]], and [[Japan]], [[The Asia Foundation]], the [[Centre for Humanitarian Dialogue]], [[Muhammadiyah]], and [[Conciliation Resources]]. When the Asia Foundation became an official member of the Third Party Monitoring Team in 2012, the Community of [[San’Egidio]] from Italy replaced the Asia Foundation in the ICG. On 24 January 2014, Philippine government chief negotiator Miriam Coronel Ferer and MILF chief negotiator Mohagher Iqbal signed a peace agreement in [[Kuala Lumpur]]. The agreement would pave the way for the creation of the new Muslim autonomous entity called "Bangsamoro" under a law to be approved by the Philippine Congress. The government aims to set up the region by 2016. The agreement calls for Muslim self-rule in parts of the southern Philippines in exchange for a deactivation of rebel forces by the MILF. MILF forces would turn over their firearms to a third party to selected by the MILF and the Philippine government. A regional police force would be established, and the Philippine military would reduce the presence of troops and help disband private armies in the area.{{cite web|url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/print/391473/ |title=Bangkok Post article |publisher=Bangkok Post article |date=2014-01-25 |accessdate=2015-02-27}} In the Agreement, the government committed to change a 37-year autonomy experiment whose current version, the [[Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao]] (ARMM), has failed to live up to the Moro people’s aspiration for freedom from a highly centralized government. ==References== {{Reflist|3}} {{Bangsamoro political entity topics}} {{Moro conflict}} [[Category:2014 in the Philippines]] [[Category:Bangsamoro peace process]] [[Category:Treaties of the Philippines]] [[Category:Peace treaties]] [[Category:Treaties involving territorial changes]] [[Category:Presidency of Benigno Aquino III]]

{{Infobox award | name = Confucius Peace Prize | current_awards = | image = | imagesize = 250px | alt = | caption = The Confucius Peace Prize. | description = Promotion of world peace from an Eastern, Confucian perspective<ref name="cnn" /> | presenter = Private committee | host = | date = {{Start date|2010|12|09}} | country = People's Republic of China | reward = | year = 2010 | year2 = | holder = [[Hun Sen]]}} {{Infobox Chinese |title=Confucius Peace Prize |s=孔子和平奖 |t=孔子和平獎 |showflag=cp |p=Kǒngzǐ Hépíngjiǎng |w=K'ung<sup>3</sup>-tzu<sup>3</sup> He<sup>2</sup>-p'ing<sup>2</sup>-chiang<sup>3</sup> |j=Hung<sup>2</sup> Zi<sup>2</sup> Wo<sup>4</sup> peng<sup>4</sup> zoeng<sup>2</sup> |y=Kung3 Dz3 He2ping2jyang2 |poj=Khóng-chú Hô-pêng Chióng }} The '''Confucius Peace Prize''' ({{zh|s=孔子和平奖|t=孔子和平獎|p=Kǒngzǐ Hépíngjiǎng}}) is a Chinese alternative to the [[Nobel Peace Prize]] established in 2010 by the Association of Chinese Indigenous Arts<ref name="Auto1H-1">[http://www.bbc.co.uk/zhongwen/trad/china/2010/12/101209_brief_china_confucius.shtml 中國官方「否認設立孔子和平獎」]</ref> in the People's Republic of China (PRC), in response to a proposal by business person Liu Zhiqin on November 17, 2010. The chairman of the committee said that the award existed to "promote world peace from an Eastern perspective", and [[Confucianism|Confucian]] peace specifically.<ref name="cnn">{{cite web |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/asiapcf/12/08/china.confucius.prize/ |title=China to hand out its own peace prize |publisher=CNN |first=Steven |last=Jiang |date=2010-12-08 |accessdate=2010-12-08}}</ref> The winner purportedly receives a cash prize of ¥100,000 RMB (US$15,000).<ref name=20101208huffingtonpost>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/12/08/confucius-peace-prize-china_n_793610.html|title=Confucius Peace Prize: China To Award Nobel Rival|work=The Huffington Post|date=8 December 2010|accessdate=11 December 2010}}</ref> Despite an attempt by China's Ministry of Culture to ban the prize<ref name="TelegraphCancel">{{cite web | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/china/8796220/Confusion-as-Confucius-Prize-scrapped.html | title=Confusion as Confucius Prize scrapped | work=The Telegraph | date=September 29, 2011 | accessdate=October 4, 2011 | author=Moore, Malcolm}}</ref><ref name="nytimes">{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/23/world/africa/zimbabwean-president-condemned-by-west-is-selected-for-chinese-peace-prize.html?_r=0 | title=Zimbawean President condemned by West is selected for Chinese peace prize |quote=The founding committee had tenuous ties to the Chinese Ministry of Culture, but a split in the committee prompted the ministry to try to ban the prize in 2011. Confucius Peace Prize|author=Richard Macauley|work=Quartz}}</ref> and [[Hun Sen]] in 2017. The Chinese government has denied having any connections with the prize.<ref name=e>[http://news.sinchew.com.my/topic/node/187484 中國否認頒「孔子和平獎」] 台灣《聯合報》</ref>
==Origins and first award== The Confucius Peace Prize originated as a response to the announcement that Chinese dissident [[Liu Xiaobo]] had won the [[2010 Nobel Peace Prize]];<ref name=confucius/><ref name=20141211nytimes/> the awarding of the prize to Liu was viewed negatively in China, with some in the government arguing that Liu did not promote "international friendship, disarmament, and peace meetings", the stated goals of the Nobel Peace Prize.<ref name="The Age: China furious at Nobel's 'violation'">{{cite news|author=Garnaut, John |url=http://www.theage.com.au/world/china-furious-at-nobels-violation-20101008-16c29.html |title=China furious at Nobel's 'violation' |date=9 October 2010 |work=The Age |location=Australia |accessdate=9 October 2010}}</ref> Competing groups staked claims to its founding, and some have links to the Ministry of Culture.<ref name=20141211nytimes/>
According to ''[[The New York Times]]'', Liu Zhiqin, a prominent Chinese scholar and banker, was the first to propose the prize, in a commentary in the ''[[Global Times]]''.<ref name="nyt"/> Liu's commentary stated, "The Nobel Peace Prize Committee won Liu Xiaobo while losing the trust of 1.3 billion Chinese people. They support a criminal while creating 1.3 billion 'dissidents' that are dissatisfied with the Nobel Committee, which is definitely a bad decision. ... China's civil society should consider setting up a 'Confucius Peace Prize', launching the evaluation and selection and finding the real Peace Prize winners from all over the world. This is the best opportunity for the Chinese to declare China's view in peace and human rights to the world."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.globaltimes.cn/content/592778.shtml |title=Confucius Prize could be weapon in battle of ideas |author=Liu Zhiqin |date=2010-11-17 |work=[[Global Times]] |accessdate=2016-10-17}}</ref>
The Association of Chinese Indigenous Arts, which is registered with the Chinese Cultural Ministry, awarded the first prize to Taiwanese politician [[Lien Chan]] in December 2010, for his contribution to developing positive ties [[Cross-Strait relations|between Taiwan and mainland China]].<ref name="NYtimes"/><ref>{{cite web |url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20101207/ap_on_re_as/as_china_nobel |title=China to award prize to rival Nobel |publisher=Yahoo! News |first=Tini |last=Tran |date=2010-12-07 |accessdate=2010-12-07}}</ref> Lien never claimed the prize.<ref name="cnn" /><ref name=confucius/><ref name="times">{{cite news |url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/front/archives/2010/12/09/2003490461 |title=Lien office denies hearing of award |author=Mo Yan-chih |date=2010-12-09 |work=[[Taipei Times]] |accessdate=2 September 2012}}</ref> China's [[Ministry of Culture (China)|Minister of Culture]] talked to the ''[[United Daily News]]'' in [[Taipei]] and stated they had never heard of this prize for Lien Chan until there was newspaper coverage.<ref name=mingpao>{{cite web |url=http://inews.mingpao.com/htm/INews/20101209/ca41348i.htm|title=中國否認頒「孔子和平獎」|trans-title=China denies awarding "Confucius Peace Prize" |work=[[Ming Pao]] |date=2010-12-09 |accessdate=2010-12-11}}</ref> The Hong Kong newspaper ''[[Ming Pao]]'' reported that the letter issued by the committee to Lien Chan did not have the Ministry of Culture's official seal.<ref name=mingpao/> The award, consisting of a small sculpture and a bundle of banknotes, was collected by a young girl in front of an audience of some 100 journalists. In the jostling, one group tried to create the "Confucius World Peace Prize" to rival the "Confucius Peace Prize".<ref name=20141211nytimes/>
==Purported cancellation and second award== In September 2011, the [[Ministry of Culture of the People's Republic of China|Ministry of Culture]] stated that it would be disbanding the organizers of Confucius Peace Prize and cancelling the prize.<ref name="CCMcancel"/> The Ministry stated in a news conference on September 17 that there was improper uses of the Ministry's name.<ref name="NYtimes"/> The Association of Chinese Indigenous Arts was quick to blame a "rogue department" for the debacle surrounding the award.<ref name="TelegraphCancel"/>
Despite the cancellation, on November 15, 2011, ''[[The Guardian]]'' reported that the original organizers had formed a new committee, the China International Peace Studies Center, in Hong Kong, where they awarded the second Confucius Peace Prize to Russian prime minister [[Vladimir Putin]]. Other contenders were [[Angela Merkel]], [[Bill Gates]], [[Jacob Zuma]], [[Kofi Annan]], [[Yuan Longping]], [[Gyaincain Norbu]] (one of the [[Panchen Lama]]s), and [[Soong Chu-yu]]. Putin won for his opposition to [[NATO]] involvement in the [[2011 Libyan Civil War|Libyan Civil War]] as well as his decision to go to war in [[Second Chechen War|Chechnya in 1999]].<ref name="bbc2011">{{Cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-china-15750979 |title=Vladimir Putin in China Confucius Peace Prize fiasco |date=2011-11-15 |accessdate=2011-11-15 |publisher=[[BBC]]}}</ref> According to the committee, Putin's "Iron hand and toughness revealed in this war impressed the Russians a lot, and he was regarded to be capable of bringing safety and stability to Russia." Putin was also praised for fulfilling his childhood dream of joining the [[KGB]]. The 2011 award, a gilded statuette of Confucius was given out on December 9 along with a certificate, although the committee did not mention a cash prize.<ref name=NYtimes/> The award ceremony featured a speech by [[Kong Qingdong]]. Kong claimed that the award accurately reflects [[Confucius]]'s original vision of peace.<ref name=20111209voanews>{{cite news |title=孔子和平奖二次颁发 获奖者再度缺席 |url=http://www.voanews.com/chinese/news/20111209-Peace-Prize-Putin-135310893.html |author=Zhang, Nan |accessdate=22 January 2012 |date=9 December 2011}}</ref>
==The award and recipients==
The prize initially carried a financial reward of CNY100,000, and has been awarded at the same time as the Nobel Peace Prize.<ref name=20141211nytimes>http://sinosphere.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/12/11/castro-awarded-confucius-peace-prize/</ref><ref name=scmp1095244/> In 2012, the China International Peace Studies Centre boasted that the new reward of $1.5 million – mostly derived from sales of works of the committee chairman's, Qiao Damo – was "more than the US$1.2 million that the recipient of this year's Nobel Peace Prize, will receive".<ref name=scmp1095244>{{cite web|url=http://www.scmp.com/news/china/article/1095244/annan-scientist-share-us15m-confucius-prize|title=Annan, scientist to share US$1.5m Confucius prize|work=South China Morning Post}}</ref> However, ''The Guardian'' reported in 2015 that the cash prize was worth CNY500,000 (£51,000).<ref name=20151022guardian>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/oct/22/zimbabwes-robert-mugabe-awarded-chinas-nobel-peace-prize|title=Zimbabwe's Robert Mugabe awarded 'China's Nobel peace prize'|author=Tom Phillips|work=The Guardian}}</ref>
=== 2012 === The shortlist for the 2012 award consisted of previous nominees [[Kofi Annan]], [[Bill Gates]], agricultural scientist [[Yuan Longping]], and [[Gyancain Norbu]], as well as [[Ban Ki-moon]], Thai prime minister [[Yingluck Shinawatra]], Chinese philosopher [[Tang Yijie]], and [[Wang Dingguo]], the last surviving female participant in Mao Zedong's [[Long March]].<ref name=20120901time>{{cite news |url=http://newsfeed.time.com/2012/09/11/chinas-confucius-prize-announces-its-wacky-2012-short-list/ |title=China's Confucius Prize Announces Its Wacky 2012 Short List |last=Boehler |first=Patrick |date=2012-09-11 |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |accessdate=19 October 2012}}</ref> Due to a tie in the voting, the committee announced that Annan and Yuan would share the award.<ref name="raymondli"/><ref name=scmp1095244/>
=== 2013 === Zen master [[Yicheng (monk)|Yicheng]] was awarded the 2013 prize for his work as chairman of the [[Buddhist Association of China]] and his contribution for Chinese Buddhism. As an addition to the Peace Prize in 2013 the first [[Confucius Art Prize]] was awarded. A gold medal was for calligrapher [[Ouyang Zhongshi]] and silver medals for Yang Lin and [[Hou Mingming]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.sina.com.cn/s/blog_5f3d33510101b045.html|title=抱歉，您要访问的页面不存在或被删除！|publisher=Sina Corp}}</ref>
=== 2014 === The ''Global Times'' reported that nominees included former Cuban president, [[Fidel Castro]], South Korean President [[Park Geun-hye]] and the UN Secretary-General [[Ban Ki-moon]].<ref name=npr370086460/> The 2014 recipient of the prize was Castro, who when leader of Cuba, "never used any violence or force when faced with problems and conflicts in international relations, especially in Cuba's relationship with the United States."<ref name="NYT2">{{cite news |url=http://sinosphere.blogs.nytimes.com//2014/12/11/castro-awarded-confucius-peace-prize |work=[[The New York Times]] |title=China's Defiant Choice for Its Peace Prize: Castro |author=Edward Wong |date=11 December 2014}}</ref><ref name="NR2">{{cite web |url=http://www.nationalreview.com/corner/394436/fidel-castros-perfect-peace-prize-jay-nordlinger |work=[[National Review]] |title=The Corner: Fidel Castro's Perfect Peace Prize |author=Jay Nordlinger |date=11 December 2014}}</ref> Castro's prize was received by a Cuban student in China.<ref name="npr370086460"/>
=== 2015 === Nominated for the award in 2015 were the [[Chinese Taoist Association]], [[Ban Ki-moon]], former Japanese prime ministers [[Yasuo Fukuda]] and [[Tomiichi Murayama]], Kazakhstan president [[Nursultan Nazarbayev]], [[Bill Gates]], Chinese-American politician [[Anna Chennault]], South Korean president [[Park Geun-hye]], [[Hsing Yun]] of the [[Fo Guang Shan]] Buddhist movement in Taiwan, and [[Robert Mugabe]] of Zimbabwe. Mugabe was eventually declared the winner for "working tirelessly to build the political and economic stability of his country, bringing peace to the people of Zimbabwe, strongly supporting pan-Africanism and African independence, and making unparalleled contributions for the renaissance of African civilisation."<ref name=20151002shanghaiist/> One of the committee's 76 members disclosed that only 36 voted for Mugabe over concerns for his record, saying that "Mugabe has been in power for such a long time that he could be easily be labelled a dictator, tyrant or despot."<ref name=20151022guardian/> Mugabe, who made a speech to the United Nations that day in which he declared that "we are not gays", did not collect his prize.<ref name=20151002shanghaiist>{{cite web|url=http://shanghaiist.com/2015/10/22/robert-mugabe-confucius-peace-prize.php|title=Zimbabwean dictator Robert Mugabe named winner of the Confucius Peace Prize, fails to show up at award ceremony|work=Shanghaiist}}</ref>
The award drew out critics of Mugabe and his human rights record. An unofficial spokesman said that the Chinese government had notified Zimbabwe that it was not associated with the conferring organisation. Mugabe repudiated the award, a spokesman saying that he "receives many prizes without even knowing, approving or receiving them. What is dramatic in this case is that oppositional interests drew a revolver at the mentioning of an honour or prize to Robert Mugabe. That is what Hitler did when someone mentioned ‘culture’ to him".<ref>https://www.newsday.co.zw/2015/10/26/mugabe-rejects-china-award/</ref>
===2016=== The prize for 2016 was awarded posthumously to three Chinese peacekeepers who were killed while serving on [[United Nations peacekeeping]] missions in Mali and South Sudan.<ref>{{cite web |title=2016年第七届孔子和平奖评选揭晓新闻发布会在京举行 |url=http://xj.cnr.cn/2014xjfw/2014xjfwws/20161031/t20161031_523234106.shtml |website=[[China National Radio|cnr.cn]] |accessdate=2016-12-17 |date=2016-10-31 |language=Chinese}}</ref> Shen Liangliang was killed while serving on the [[United Nations Multidimensional Integrated Stabilization Mission in Mali|mission in Mali]] on May 31, 2016<ref>{{cite web |title=Tributes for Chinese peacekeeper Shen Liangliang, killed by jihadists in attack on UN Mali mission |url=http://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy-defence/article/1969130/tributes-chinese-peacekeeper-shen-liangliang-killed |website=[[South China Morning Post]] |accessdate=2016-12-17 |date=2016-06-08}}</ref> while Yang Shupeng and Li Lei were killed while serving on the [[United Nations Mission in South Sudan|mission in South Sudan]] on July 10, 2016.<ref>{{cite web |title=Funeral ceremony of Chinese UN peacekeepers held in China's Henan |url=http://www.globaltimes.cn/content/995787.shtml |website=[[Global Times]] |accessdate=2016-12-17 |date=2016-07-21}}</ref>
===2017=== Candidates for the 2017 prize were [[Hun Sen]], [[Gyaincain Norbu]], [[Rodrigo Duterte]], [[Bashar al-Assad]], [[Angela Merkel]], [[Hsing Yun]], the [[Chinese Taoist Association]], [[Xuecheng (monk)|Xuecheng]], [[Pope Francis]], and Yancan.<ref>{{cite web|title=China's Confucius Peace Prize courts yet more controversy|url=https://asia.nikkei.com/Politics-Economy/Policy-Politics/China-s-Confucius-Peace-Prize-courts-yet-more-controversy?page=1|website=Nikkei Asian Review|accessdate=26 December 2017|date=4 December 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=2017年第八届孔子和平奖候选人公告 新闻发布会在京举行|url=http://finance.china.com/jykx/news/11179727/20170928/25126855_all.html|website=china.com|accessdate=26 December 2017|language=zh|date=28 December 2017}}</ref> The Prime Minister of Cambodia Hun Sen was announced to be the winner.<ref>{{cite web|title=深圳永乐董事受邀出席2017年第八届孔子和平奖评选揭晓新闻发布会|url=http://szylart.com/gszx/80.html|website=szylart.com|accessdate=26 December 2017|language=zh|date=13 December 2017}}</ref>
==Response to Confucius Peace Prize== Chinese sources have not treated the prize seriously. The Ministry of Culture of the People's Republic of China denied any cooperation with the Association of Chinese Indigenous Arts to present the prize,<ref name=e /> stating that prior to foreign press reports, the Ministry "had never even heard of the name". The ministry added that "the government is very careful" and "if the government genuinely intended to establish a 'Confucius Peace prize', it would not have been implemented so sloppily."<ref name=e /> Mainland media did not widely report about the prize in 2010,<ref name=e /> with journalists claiming that they had come across neither the organization nor the prize, believing it to be "闹剧" (a farce).<ref name=e />
Netizens in Mainland China responded to the Prize with widespread humour as well as derision, referring to the prize organizers as "bullheaded dreaming idiots", "jokes", and "embarrassments to Chinese",<ref name="Auto1H-2">[http://hk.apple.nextmedia.com/news/art/20101206/14736240 《京報籲設「孔子和平獎」惹恥笑》] - 蘋果日報 - 6-12-2010</ref> as well as suspicion that the prize was a practical joke.<ref name=e />
The Confucius Peace Prize's first winner, Lien Chan, claimed he had not officially heard that he had won; an aide said that they had only received "secondhand information from journalists".<ref name="nyt">{{Cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/12/09/world/asia/09china.html |title=China's Answer to Nobel Mystifies Its Winner |first=Edward |last=Wong |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=2010-12-08 |accessdate=2010-12-08}}</ref> This contradicted a statement in the ''[[Global Times]]'' by the chairman of the Confucius Peace Prize Committee, Tan Liuchang, that Lien had been contacted by the committee.<ref name="global">{{cite news |author=Liu, Linlin |url=http://china.globaltimes.cn/society/2010-12/600306.html |title=NGO creates 'Peace Prize' |date=9 December 2010 |work=Global Times |accessdate=15 November 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110905073941/http://china.globaltimes.cn/society/2010-12/600306.html |archivedate=5 September 2011 |df= }}</ref> Tsai Chi-chang, a spokesperson for the opposition [[Democratic Progressive Party]] in Taiwan, said the award should not be taken seriously.<ref name="times"/>
Officials from the Taiwanese government are reported to have found the award of the Confucius Peace Prize to Lien Chan "amusing".<ref name=confucius>{{cite web|last=Martina |first=Michael |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE6B81YC20101209 | title=China stood up by winner of 'Confucius peace prize' |agency=Reuters |date=9 December 2010 |accessdate=12 December 2010}}</ref> When asked by a reporter about the prize, a spokesman for Vladimir Putin said that he had heard about the award through the press, but that "we do not know much about the prize."<ref name=NYtimes/>
Western media, however, have reacted to the prize as genuine. ''[[The Economist]]'' compared the substitute award to the reaction by [[Nazi Germany]] and the creation of the [[German National Prize for Art and Science]] after [[Carl von Ossietzky]] was prohibited from accepting his Nobel Prize in 1935, as well as the [[Soviet Union]] preventing [[Andrei Sakharov]] from accepting his Nobel Peace Prize in 1975.<ref name="Asia view">{{cite news |title=The empty chair |work=[[The Economist]] |url=https://www.economist.com/blogs/asiaview/2010/12/china_and_nobel_peace_prize |date=12 December 2010 |accessdate=12 December 2010}}</ref> ''[[National Review]]'' likewise compared the prize to Hitler's and Stalin's responses to the Nobel Peace Prize.<ref name="NR1">{{cite web |url=http://www.nationalreview.com/corner/254791/nazis-and-soviets-jay-nordlinger |work=[[National Review]] |title=The Corner: Like the Nazis and the Soviets ... |author=Jay Nordlinger |date=8 December 2010}}</ref> ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'' has described the prize as "[s]omething of a [[Internet troll|trolling]] exercise".<ref>{{cite web |last1=Keating |first1=Joshua |title="Chinese Nobel" Awarded to Dictator and Mass Murderer Robert Mugabe |url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/the_slatest/2015/10/23/robert_mugabe_wins_2015_confucius_prize.html |website=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]] |accessdate=2015-10-25 |date=2015-10-23}}</ref>
The ''Global Times'' reported that the five 2011 nominees were selected based on their being the winners of an online poll.<ref name="global"/> However, when asked about the details of the online vote, the organizer said they failed to carry it out because of "technical problems", The ''South China Morning Post'' reported.<ref name=20101209scmp>{{cite web | url=http://topics.scmp.com/news/china-news-watch/article/Confusion-Prize-brings-Beijing-doubtful-reward | title=Confusion Prize brings Beijing doubtful reward | work=South China Morning Post | date=December 9, 2010 | accessdate=November 15, 2011 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120716100223/http://topics.scmp.com/news/china-news-watch/article/Confusion-Prize-brings-Beijing-doubtful-reward | archivedate=July 16, 2012 | df= }}</ref>
==Winners==
* 2010 – [[Lien Chan]] * 2011 – [[Vladimir Putin]] * 2012 – [[Kofi Annan]] and [[Yuan Longping]] * 2013 – [[Yicheng (monk)|Yicheng]] * 2014 – [[Fidel Castro]] * 2015 – [[Robert Mugabe]]<ref>{{cite news|title=村山元首相、最終選考に残るも固辞… 受賞者は「独裁」で名高いジンバブエ・ムガベ大統領… (Former Japanese Prime Minister Murayama refuses in the final round, so the Confucius Peace Prize winner is Zimbabwean President Mugabe|url=http://www.sankei.com/world/news/151010/wor1510100035-n1.html|accessdate=17 October 2015|publisher=Sankei}}</ref> * 2016 – [[Shen Liangliang]] ({{lang|zh|[[:zh:申亮亮|申亮亮]]}}), [[Yang Shupeng]] ({{lang|zh|[[:zh:杨树朋|杨树朋]]}}), and [[Li Lei (peacekeeper)|Li Lei]] ({{lang|zh|[[:zh:李磊|李磊]]}})<ref>{{cite news|title=2016年第七届孔子和平奖评选揭晓新闻发布会在京举行|url=http://xj.cnr.cn/2014xjfw/2014xjfwws/20161031/t20161031_523234106.shtml}}</ref> * 2017 – [[Hun Sen]]

{{Infobox company | name = Cygilant, Inc. | type = [[Private company|Private]] | foundation = 2001 | location_city = [[Boston, Massachusetts]] | location_country = United States | key_people = Vijay Basani, President/CEO | industry = [[Technology]], [[Information security|Information Security]] | homepage = {{URL|www.cygilant.com}} }}
'''Cygilant, Inc''', (originally named '''EiQ Networks, Inc.'''), is a [[Boston, Massachusetts|Boston]]-based security [[software-as-a-service]] (SaaS) company focused on [[information security]] and compliance objectives.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://patch.com/massachusetts/acton/security-firm-leaves-acton-boston-0 |title= Security Firm Leaves Acton for Boston |publisher=Patch |date=2015-02-24 |accessdate=2015-04-09| first=Jason| last=Claffey}}</ref> EiQ Networks’ origins are in analysis of log files across web servers, file servers, firewalls and other network devices,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.networkworld.com/article/2896812/data-center/new-products-of-the-week-03-16-2015.html#slide10 |title= New products of the week |publisher=Network World |date=2015-03-16 |accessdate=2015-04-09| first=Brandon| last=Butler}}</ref> but moved into the [[Security information and event management|security information and event management (SIEM)]] market.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.scmagazine.com/eiq-networks-securevue-v366/review/4146/ |title= Product Information |publisher=SC Magazine |date=2014-04-01 |accessdate=2015-04-09| first=Peter| last= Stephenson}}</ref>
==Company== EiQ Networks, Inc. was founded in 2001. EiQ Networks’ global headquarters are in [[Boston, Massachusetts]], with additional in Hyderabad, India. EiQ Networks is a closely held private company. The company completed its first institutional round raising $10 million in January 2009 led by [[Venrock]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.pehub.com/2009/01/eiqnetworks-raises-10-million/ |title= eIQnetworks Raises $10 Million |publisher=Private Equity Hub |date=2009-01-20 |accessdate=2015-04-09}}</ref> The company received an additional $2 million in September 2010<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.xconomy.com/boston/2010/09/03/eiqnetworks-lands-2000000-new-funding/ |title= eIQnetworks Lands $2,000,000 New Funding |publisher=Xconomy |date=2010-09-03 |accessdate=2015-04-09}}</ref> and also raised $750,000 in debt financing in June 2012.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/boston/blog/mass-high-tech/2012/06/eiqnetworks-secures-750k-debt-fundraise.html |title= eIQnetworks secures $750K debt fundraise |publisher=Boston Business Journal |date=2012-06-15 |accessdate=2015-04-19| first=Patricia| last=Resende}}</ref> Santa Monica-based [[Arrowroot Capital]] invested into EiQ Networks in 2014, and the Company has since experienced substantially higher growth rates driven by the ramp-up in the company's inside sales organization. <ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.eiqnetworks.com/about-us/news-room/press-releases?pr=eiq-networks-raises-9-55-million-in-series-c-growth-capital-led-by-arrowroot-capital.html |title= EiQ Networks Raises $9.55 Million In Series C Growth Capital Led By Arrowroot Capital |publisher=EiQ Networks |date=2016-01-16 |accessdate=2015-04-19| first=Patricia| last=Resende}}</ref> EiQ Networks was co-founded by Vijay Basani and Jay Reddy. In September 2017, the company announced that it has raised an additional $7 Million in funding and would rebrand as Cygilant, Inc. <ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.prweb.com/releases/2017/09/prweb14710890.htm |title= EiQ Networks Raises $9.55 Million In Series C Growth Capital Led By Arrowroot Capital |publisher=PrWeb |date=2017-09-19 |accessdate=2017-11-02}}</ref> Prior to founding EiQ Networks, Basani and Reddy co-founded WebManage Technologies, which was acquired by [[NetApp]] in 2000.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.streamingmedia.com/Articles/News/Online-Video-News/Network-Appliance-Buys-WebManage-for-$75-Million-63056.aspx |title=Network Appliance Buys WebManage for $75 Million |publisher=Streaming Media |date=2000-09-05 |accessdate=2015-04-09| first=Jose| last=Alvear}}</ref>
== Relationship with the security community ==
On Feb. 8th 2018 the company mocked and insulted several security researchers on [[Twitter]]. They also tweeted "Thanks for the free marketing, kids! #HowYouDoMarketing". Later the tweets were deleted and the company apologized.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.zdnet.com/article/security-firm-cygilant-apologies-after-social-media-meltdown/|title=Security firm Cygilant apologizes after social media meltdown|last=Whittaker|first=Zack|work=ZDNet|access-date=2018-02-09|language=en}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Information security|Information Security]] * [[Security information and event management|Security Information and Event Management (SIEM)]] * [[Boston, Massachusetts]] * [[Venrock]]

{{one source|date=September 2017}} {{Infobox political party |country = the Republic of Macedonia | name = Democratic Party of Albanians |native_name = Демократска Партија на Албанците
Partia Demokratike Shqiptare |colorcode = black |logo = Partia Demokratike Shqiptare.svg |logo_size = 230px |leader = [[Menduh Thaçi]] |foundation = June 1997 |ideology = {{nowrap|[[Albanians in the Republic of Macedonia|Albanian]] [[minority politics|minority interests]]
[[Populism]]
[[Conservatism]]{{cite web|first=Wolfram|last=Nordsieck|title=Macedonia|website=Parties and Elections in Europe|url=http://www.parties-and-elections.eu/macedonia.html|year=2016|accessdate=6 June 2018}}}} |position = [[Centre-right]] to [[right-wing]] |international = [[International Democrat Union]] (observer) |european = ''None'' |europarl = |headquarters = |colours = Red, Black (Colours of the [[Albanian flag]]) |seats1_title = [[Macedonian Parliament]] |seats1 = {{Composition bar|2|120|hex=black}} |seats2_title = [[Municipalities of the Republic of Macedonia|Mayors]] |seats2 = {{Composition bar|2|81|hex=black}} |website = [http://www.gurra-pdsh.org http://www.gurra-pdsh.org] }} The '''Democratic Party of Albanians''' ({{lang-sq|Partia Demokratike Shqiptare}}; {{lang-mk|Демократска партија на Албанците}}, ''Demokratska Partija na Albancite'') or DPA is a [[List of political parties in the Republic of Macedonia|political party]] of ethnic [[Albanians in the Republic of Macedonia]]. The DPA is a merger of the Party for Democratic Prosperity of Albanians (PDPA) and the [[People's Democratic Party (Macedonia)|People's Democratic Party]] (NDP) which took place in June 1997. The former party was established in 1994 after some radical members of the [[Party for Democratic Prosperity]], led by Menduh Thaçi and [[Arbën Xhaferi]], left the PDP and the latter party was founded in August 1990 as a more radical opponent of the PDP. [[File:DPA in Tetovo, Macedonia.JPG|thumb|left|200px|DPA sign in Tetovo]] At the [[Macedonian parliamentary election, 2002|2002 legislative elections]], the party won 5.2% of the popular vote and 7 out of 120 seats. The party lost its status as a government party due to the defeat of the VMRO-DPMNE. At the [[Macedonian parliamentary election, 2006|2006 parliamentary elections]], the party increased its support, winning 7.5% of the vote and 11 seats. After the elections the DPA entered the government coalition led by the [[VMRO-DPMNE]]. DPA returned to opposition after the [[Macedonian parliamentary election, 2008|2008 legislative early election]]. In the [[Macedonian parliamentary election, 2011|2011 parliamentary election]], DPA received 5.9% of the popular vote, winning 8 seats. This is a loss of 3 seats from the previous election.{{cite news |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=136984879 |title=Conservative Leader Claims 3rd Term In Macedonia |work=[[NPR]] |date=2011-06-06 |accessdate=2011-06-06}} == References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.gurra-pdsh.org Official web site] {{sq icon}} {{en icon}} {{Macedonian political parties}} [[Category:Albanian nationalist parties]] [[Category:Political parties established in 1997]] [[Category:Albanian political parties in the Republic of Macedonia]] [[Category:Political parties of minorities]] [[Category:Ethnic political parties]] {{RMacedonia-party-stub}}

__NOTOC__ {{Infobox scientist |name = Diana Leafe Christian |image =<!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Diana Leafe Christian.jpg|thumb|right| ]] --> |residence = [[North Carolina]], [[United States]] |fields = [[Permaculture]] }} [[File:Community Circle at OUR Ecovillage.jpg|right|thumb|Participants in a 2006 workshop led by Christian at [[O.U.R. Ecovillage]], British Columbia]] '''Diana Leafe Christian''' is an author, former editor of ''[[Communities (magazine)|Communities]]'' magazine, and nationwide speaker and workshop presenter on starting new [[ecovillages]], on building communities, and on [[sustainability]]. She lives in an [[off-grid]] homestead at [[Earthaven Ecovillage]] in the [[Blue Ridge Mountains]] of [[North Carolina]], U.S.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thestar.com/News/article/215859|title=Living green before their time|date=20 May 2007|work=[[Toronto Star]]|accessdate=17 March 2010}}</ref><ref name=jacobs>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/06/11/weekinreview/11jacobs.html|title= Ideas & Trends; Extreme Makeover, Commune Edition |last=Jacobs |first=Andrew |date=11 June 2006|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=27 December 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vueweekly.com/article.php?id=6988|title=From homeless to village people?|last=Kelly|first=Joe|date=19 September 2007|work=[[Vue Weekly]]|accessdate=17 March 2010}}</ref> She has said that living in an intentional community "is the longest, most expensive, personal growth workshop you will ever take."<ref name=practicaltools>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nlMDckgqU30 |title=Practical Tools to Grow an Intentional Community |publisher=Peak Moment Channel|year=2007}} (interview)</ref>
==Biography== Christian grew up in Los Angeles. She learned to write at what she calls a "real-life school of writing".
==Published works== Christian is the author of two books designed to help people who want to join or start their own ecovillages or other [[intentional communities]]. In ''Creating a Life Together: Practical Tools to Grow Ecovillages and Intentional Communities'', she uses success stories, cautionary tales, and step-by-step advice to cover typical time-frames and costs; the role of founders; getting started as a group; vision documents; power, governance, and decision-making; legal structures; finding and financing land; zoning issues; sustainable site plans; selecting new members; and good process and communication skills for dealing well with conflict.
In ''Finding Community: How to Join an Ecovillage or Intentional Community'', she covers researching, visiting, evaluating, and joining communities.
During the 1970s and 80s Christian wrote articles for ''New Age'' magazine, ''[[Yoga Journal]]'', and ''East West Journal''. She hosted radio interview programs in Hawaii and in northern California.<ref name="about">{{cite web|url=http://www.dianaleafechristian.org/about_diana.html|title=Diana Leafe Christian: About|publisher=Diana Leafe Christian}}</ref>
In the early 1990s Christian published a newsletter, ''Growing Community'', about starting new communities. From 1993 to 2007<ref name="about" /> she was editor of [[Communities magazine|''Communities'' magazine]], a quarterly publication of the nonprofit [[Fellowship for Intentional Community]] (FIC), about intentional communities and organized neighborhoods in North America.
==Public speaking== Christian speaks, leads workshops, and shows slide presentations on ecovillages in the US and Canada, including [[Ecovillage Training Center]] at [[The Farm (Tennessee)|The Farm]] in Tennessee, Los Angeles Eco-Village, [[Lost Valley Educational Center]] in Oregon, O.U.R. Ecovillage in British Columbia, and Easton Mountain Center in New York. At a 2015 engagement, she spoke on the application of [[permaculture]] design principles to [[ecovillage]]s' financial, legal, and social aspects, in San Diego.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.permaculturevoices.com/pv2/ |title=Permaculture Voices |accessdate=2015-06-19}} (speaker listing)</ref>
She has led workshops at the North American Cohousing Conference, Twin Oaks Communities Conference, and FIC's Art of Community gathering. Her articles on ecovillages and intentional communities have appeared in publications ranging from ''Mother Earth News'' to Canada's ''This Magazine''. She has been quoted in ''[[The New York Times]]'',<ref name=jacobs/> ''[[Harper's]]'' magazine,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.harpers.org/archive/2006/08/0081156 |title= Imagine there's no oil: Scenes from a liberal apocalypse|last=Urstadt |first=Bryant |date= August 2006|work=[[Harper's Magazine]]|accessdate=27 Dec 2010}}</ref> and ''[[AARP Magazine]]'', and has been interviewed by ''Vision'' magazine, New Dimensions Radio, [[NPR]], and the BBC.
==Books== * 2003, ''Creating a Life Together: Practical Tools to Grow Ecovillages and Intentional Communities'', [[New Society Publishers]]; New Ed edition, {{ISBN|0-86571-471-1}}, foreword by [[Patch Adams]] * 2006, [http://ecosociete.org/livres/vivre-autrement ''Vivre autrement: écovillages, communautés et cohabitats''], Les éditions Écosociété, {{ISBN|2-923165-24-1}}, Préface de [[Jacques Languirand]] * 2007, ''Finding Community: How to Join an Ecovillage or Intentional Community '', New Society Publishers, {{ISBN|0-86571-578-5}} <!-- add books listing -->
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.DianaLeafeChristian.org Christian's personal website] * [http://wiki.ic.org/wiki/Diana_Leafe_Christian Intentional Community Wiki page] on Christian * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nlMDckgqU30 "Practical Tools to Grow an Intentional Community"], interview on YouTube

{{about|a particular use of the term "electoralism"|the more general sense of electoral{{\}}election-based politics|Election}}
'''Electoralism''' is a term first used by [[Terry Karl]], professor of [[political science]] at [[Stanford University]], to describe a "half-way" transition from [[authoritarian]] rule toward [[democracy|democratic]] rule. As a topic in the [[dominant party system]] political science literature, electoralism describes a situation where the transition out of hard-authoritarian rule is initiated and managed by the incumbent regime. However, due to the dominant position of the incumbent regime throughout the transition process, the transition fails to attain the institutional qualities of [[liberal democracy]]. Other terms, such as guided transition or managed transition have been used to describe this process.
Under electoralism, the regime essentially conducts the electoral aspects of democratic governance in a relatively 'free and fair' manner. Massive acts of [[voting fraud]] and election-day intimidation are essentially absent. However, other features of democracy, such as the [[rule of law]] and institutional [[separation of powers]], are absent under electoralism. The entire election process is skewed in favor of the incumbent regime. The media tends to ignore or paint the opposition in a negative light, the high court and election commission tends to make judgements in favor of the incumbent, and on some occasions, opposition rallies are denied or canceled by the police.
Some examples include: * [[History of Tanzania#United Republic of Tanzania|Tanzania]] after 1992 * [[History of Turkey#Republic of Turkey|Turkey]] after 2002 * [[History of Kenya#Independent Kenya|Kenya]] after 1991 * [[History of Mexico#The end of PRI's hegemony|Mexico]] between the late 1980s and 2000. * [[History of Russia|Russian Federation]] after 1991<ref>Rose, Richard & Munro, Neil: <u>Elections Without Order</u> Cambridge University Press, 2002 (p. 42)</ref>
== References == {{reflist}} Giliomee, Herman and Charles Simkins (eds). (1999). The Awkward Embrace: One-Party Domination and Democracy. Overseas Publisher Association.
